awd_titl_txt: Interactions of shapeable boundaries with flowing fluids:Experiments and mathematical modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
Many processes in nature, industry and everyday life involve the coupled motions of fluids and compliant objects or boundaries. Understanding these complex interactions is challenging but important if these effects are to be exploited or controlled in engineering, industrial and technological applications. The proposed projects identify key problems from the natural and applied sciences yet to be studied as fluid-structure interactions and which stand to benefit from laboratory experiments and mathematical modeling. Focus areas include solid boundaries that change shape due to fluidic erosion and dissolution, as well as liquid interfaces and films reshaped by flows. The proposed work focuses on the fundamental interactions to be revealed by experiments and reproduced in models. These studies will provide insight into the processes that shape natural landforms and how such effects can be used in chemical, pharmaceutical and manufacturing applications. The program will also train and educate undergraduate and graduate students towards careers in the mathematical sciences and engineering, and it will further national math and science education initiatives through the engagement of New York City high school students from under-represented groups.

Fundamental flow-boundary interaction mechanisms will be studied through experiments on the evolution of erodible boundaries by internal flows, the dissolution of surfaces due to self-generated convective flows, and the flow-driven deformation and inflation of films and interfaces. These settings are chosen to closely link with mathematical models to be developed based on the relevant fluid dynamics (e.g. boundary-layer and free-streamline theories) coupled to boundary evolution equations (e.g. shear-stress erosion laws, Fick's law of diffusion, and the Young-Laplace law). Experiments and models will inform one another to understand the role of boundary-flow feedback processes in dictating the shape dynamics, with emphasis placed on characterizing the singular geometries (e.g. corners, spikes, surface patterning) and singular events (e.g. bifurcations, geometric shocks, rupture) that play critical roles in these processes. How these results extend to more complex geometries (e.g. erodible/dissolvable flow networks) and in more complex situations (e.g. shape evolution coupled to free motion in a fluid) will also be explored. A broader goal is to extend the reach of fluid-structure interactions by expanding the scope of problems viewed in this way and by providing new techniques. Broader scientific impacts pertain to better understanding flow-driven erosion, corrosion, melting and dissolution in the context of geomorphological, chemical and industrial processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
These projects significantly advanced the understanding of problems involving interactions of fluid flows with deformable surfaces and solids that change shape or move in response to flows. The work proceeded along parallel directions in several topical areas selected for their fundamental importance to the natural sciences and potential relevance to engineering and industrial applications. Efforts to understand how flows reshape solids during erosion included studies of erodible objects fixed in imposed flows, freely moving bodies in flight, flow through channels with erodible walls, and flow over erodible topographies. These studies led to the discovery of new shapes and mechanisms that relate to natural structures such as landforms and help to explain how they develop. Similarly, the dissolution of solids immersed in liquids was shown to carve unique shapes due to fluid flows generated by the dissolving process itself. A related problem of ice melting in water revealed how the resulting shapes are highly sensitive to the temperature of the water due to spontaneously generated flows. Finally, the work included studies of how liquid films and interfaces respond to flows and how water waves can be used to manipulate submerged objects. All projects led to the development of laboratory experiments, mathematical models, and computational simulations that were used to cross-validate all methods, identify the major phenomena, and determine the key fluid dynamical mechanisms. The research was also integrated into educational and outreach activities that were aimed at engaging and training young researchers, preparing them for careers in technical sectors, and developing and improving education at New York University.

The major scientific and engineering merits of these studies include: 1) establishing experimental systems for precisely characterizing shape-changing fluid mechanical processes such as erosion, dissolving and melting; 2) developing and implementing new codes that can effectively and accurately simulate such processes; 3) formulating math models that help to reveal the mechanisms and identify strategies for controlling them; 4) combining these methods to help explain how natural formations come about and how their shapes can be used to infer environmental or climate conditions; and 5) providing insights and methods that can be usefully applied in  contexts such as pharmaceutical, industrial and manufacturing technologies. This work has also positively impacted society more broadly by: 1) enhancing the preparedness of postdoctoral researchers through career training and promotion; 2) educating and training of graduate students, thereby contributing to the skill level of the national workforce; 3) education and training of undergraduates, including those under-represented in STEM fields; 4) education and engagement of high school students, especially young women considering careers in science, engineering and mathematics; 5) contributing to the general preparedness and skill level of the workforce by teaching a course on the constructive interaction of experiments and mathematics; 6) contributing to the general preparedness of undergraduate students through a demo room initiative that enhances teaching; and  7) engaging the general public through outreach program and the public media.

 


Last Modified: 11/14/2022
Modified by: Leif G Ristroph
